Award.AwardTitle: Earthcube IA: Collaborative Proposal: Interdisciplinary Earth Data Alliance as a Model for Integrating Earthcube Technology Resources and Engaging the Broad Community
Award.AbstractNarration:
A fundamental requirement for EarthCube is access to a comprehensive spectrum of well-curated, reliably re-usable, and seamlessly interoperable scientific data, but this does not exist today with many Geoscience domains still lacking sustainable data services. This project is a collaboration between an established data facility in the solid Earth sciences, IEDA (Interdisciplinary Earth Data Alliance), three scientifically related data communities in the solid Earth sciences that lack data facilities (deep seafloor processes, mineral physics, polar cryosphere), a research data collection (MetPetDB), a group of computer scientists that specialize in distributed information systems and interoperability, and a social scientist to re-structure the IEDA data facility, both organizationally and architecturally, to create the pilot of a multi-institutional and multi-disciplinary alliance of data providers. The goal is to create a model for other data facilities to partner with so far ?underserved? data communities to broaden integration of Geoscience domains into EarthCube, and advance both interdisciplinary and discipline-specific data science, while realizing economies of scale by sharing common data services.

Using IEDA as a testbed, the project will adopt elements of three EarthCube technologies that have been or are being developed by EarthCube Building Block projects: CINERGI (Community INventory of EarthCube Resources for Geoscience Interoperability), GeoWS (Geoscience Web Services), and GeoLink (Semantic Web technology), to build the architecture of the alliance, thereby testing, validating, and potentially improving these technologies. The technical work will focus on creating a flexible and scalable framework that will allow a growing number of partner systems to plug into shared capabilities such as applications for integrated data discovery and data submission and contribute their resources. Architectural changes at IEDA will go hand-in-hand with the transition of IEDA?s organizational structure toward the envisioned multi-institutional alliance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The collection and analysis of data are central to research in the Earth and space sciences. Data drive discoveries and knowledge and need to be discoverable, accessible, and reusable. In order to support the data needs of researchers, NSF and other federal agencies fund the development and operation of databases and data facilities that curate research data for the community. These data facilities, which mostly handle data of a specific discipline or a specific type - for example, earthquake data or mineral data - provide indispensable services to the science community ensuring discovery, access, reusability, attribution, and preservation of data as essential products of and resources for scientific research. 

This project, a collaboration among 5 institutions, was funded through NSF’s EarthCube program to explore ways how data facilities in the Earth sciences could collaborate more closely to make management of data more efficient and consistent, data services more reliable and sustainable, and to enable cross-disciplinary research scenarios that take advantage of a unified platform for data management. The goal was to establish an alliance of data providers that would share hardware and software for data storage and computing; that would align technologies, data standards, workflows, and policies; pool technical expertise and work together on workforce training and education; and develop integrated services for data access and data submission to better support users. The proposed approach was to re-architecture the NSF-supported data facility IEDA (Interdisciplinary Earth Data Alliance), both technically and organizationally, in a way it would support the development and operation of data systems in the alliance, specifically those that provide essential services to smaller data communities, but that lack resources for a standards-compliant sustainable operation as trusted data repositories.

Project deliverables comprised technical developments, several workshops and community outreach activities. Our technical accomplishments included: (1) development of the IEDA Data Submission Hub (DaSH) prototype that was designed to provide researchers with a single point of entry for depositing their data in one of the different alliance data systems; (2) development of a framework for maintaining shared vocabularies that support data discovery across all participating alliance partners; (3) development of a shared metadata catalog that unifies dataset descriptions across alliance partners while at the same time providing the necessary depth of metadata expected in each domain; (4) work with the EarthCube CINERGI/Data Discovery Hub projects making data in alliance systems discoverable via the Data Discovery Hub search portal; (5) enhancing the Data Discovery prototype by enabling spatial querying within polar regions, as one of the alliance partners was the US Antarctic Program Data Center. We organized several workshops that 1) brought together representatives of data facilities and databases to define the value proposition, scope, and organizational structure of the alliance; 2) facilitated community building around data communities in different disciplines such as mineral physics, and resulted in defining, for example, requirements for data documentation and for data deposition formats to make data reusable; and 3) develop a shared vision and roadmap for the development of infrastructure shared among major data facilities in the Earth sciences. 

The initial kick-off workshop of the Alliance Testbed Project, which was facilitated by a social scientist, produced recommendations for the alliance structure and proposed a business model for its operation and growth. Ultimately, this alliance model did not find the required level of support from the NSF and the community, which became apparent in the reviews of the IEDA renewal proposal in 2016, and was abandoned. At roughly the same time, in 2018, discussions at meetings of the Council of Data Facilities revealed broad interest in exploring options for shared infrastructure services that could help data facilities better address a number of urgent challenges including: rapidly expanding volume of data that they need to manage, requiring new levels of storage and network capacity and, consequentially, resources and team expertise; the need to comply with international guidelines for trustworthy operation of services, including transparent and standards-based data curation procedures, licensing, risk management, security, and sustainability; continuously evolving opportunities for enhancing machine access and interoperability of data holdings; and stagnant or declining budgets. Shared infrastructure is expected to make operations more efficient and sustainable, while also leading to better alignment of policies and procedures across data facilities, and opening opportunities for joint developments and innovation to meet future needs. In agreement with NSF, we used remaining funds of the project to support two surveys of data facilities regarding their infrastructure needs and a workshop in July 2019 that resulted in a common vision of shared infrastructure of data facilities and a plan to move forward with its development. The Shared Infrastructure Pilot of the Council of Data Facilities is the most relevant outcome of this project and likely to have a lasting impact on the way research data infrastructure will evolve in the US Earth sciences.
